episode_title: From Middle School Teacher to $1.7M in 10 Months Launching a Drywall Business
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.75)
All right, welcome to Nickonomics. I am with Jared Cotter and on today's episode you are going to hear how a middle school teacher went from no experience to 1.7 million dollars in 10 months launching a drywall business. In a space he had nothing to do with using kind of his secret method of closing at three times the average rate. It's pretty incredible. When I saw it on Twitter, I reached out to him and said, I have to know the entire story and you're going to hear it today.


for the next 30, 45 minutes. So strap in. So my first question, Jared, to you is, what the freak is your business? Like, what is a drywall business?


Jared Kotter (00:38.469)
Yeah, so we do drywall for custom homes. I mean, we can do drywall in anything, finishing a basement or you have a hole in wall, but like the golden sauce really is in custom homes. My business, I actually don't own the entire drywall business. I just am some contracted salesman for another guy who owns the drywall business. And so I just go out and find new jobs and we can get into kind how I do that. then.


get a percentage of the profit on every job I bring in. It's great.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:09.774)
Okay, so a guy with zero experience, zero sales experience, other than being an LDS missionary, where did you get this idea from? Like how did this even pop into your head? Because you were a middle school teacher.


Jared Kotter (01:20.993)
Yeah. Yeah. As a middle school teacher. Um, yeah, well, I'll be honest. So my, my older brothers, uh, had done this same model previously, uh, for someone else and he'd done it for a few years. Um, had great success then different reasons broke off and started his own drywall business. And so, uh, he had just, um, he had kind of planted the idea in my head forever ago. And then as middle school teacher, I wanted.


I really wanted to retire my wife and also own my schedule and so I had to do something. Had a bunch of different ideas and then this one just seemed like the highest probability chance of success in a relatively short amount of time. And so yeah, we dove in.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:04.43)
Were you looking at a bunch of different businesses? Were you looking at franchising or starting your own business, buying a business? What did that process look like for you?


Jared Kotter (02:10.594)
Ton of different ideas. Yeah, ton of different ideas. And I had actually dabbled in a couple others too. So like first business I started was a lacrosse training business. I played in college and did that. And that went relatively well. Made a few bucks here and there, but hard to scale and very seasonal, stuff like that. so needed something that would retire my wife. Basically it was the goal. So yeah, dabbled in a bunch of things.


kind of like for a long time, just had my feet in too many, in too many ponds or whatever, know, like dabbling in too many things. And then like just had to come to Jesus moment like, I need to pick one thing, all in and just assess like what has the greatest likelihood of success and felt like this was it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:01.91)
You were launching a bunch of different things? You were trying to make money at a bunch of different Like what were you doing?


Jared Kotter (03:04.738)
mean, launching is like probably too generous. was just like, it was just like a lot of like entrepreneur, like just I'm going to research this forever and then not do anything about it or like do the first step, you know, and just that like analysis paralysis, like, not this. And I'm going to try this and didn't really ever commit any one thing. Wasn't focusing this like a million women in red dress, you know?


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:10.346)
You


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:31.006)
Yeah, no, no, that makes total sense. Why this then? Was it because you'd seen your brothers do it and be successful?


Jared Kotter (03:36.322)
Yeah, I'd seen it being done before and felt like it was the simple, like one of, if not the simplest of the options I was considering also. Just like the recipe for success and doing it is just very, very straightforward. And I could see the math, like, you know, if I contact this many people and I'll close this many and then generate this income. And so, you being a former athlete, like the steps.


Like it was very clear to me, like if I do this work, I will get this outcome. And so yeah, that's kind of why I landed on this.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:07.214)
Hmm.


You know, you have you have two of like my five my five favorite attributes, which are college athlete and LDS return missionary. Like there's something about college athletes because there's a lot of college athletes that don't go on to play professional sports, but they were disciplined and they had to. Of course they were competitive, but. When you become a college athlete, it's just about your skill. It's can you train? Can you be consistent? Can you eat right?


Can you prep for those games? Can you be a team player? I think there's just a lot of really good attributes that you develop as a, as a college athlete. And then obviously as an LDS missionary, you just told no over and over and over. And so you've got to figure out how to talk to you, how to sell people, how to actually communicate well. So it's, it's good that you had that skill set, but you actually weren't using those. You're like as a middle school teacher, I mean, maybe trying to convince kids to shut up so they could listen to the lesson or something, but you weren't really using those skill sets.


Jared Kotter (05:04.194)
Sure. Yeah, mean, no, being a middle school teacher was awesome, like really meaningful, yeah, it was, yeah, it felt like there was, I could use my talents in other ways too. And, and especially for me, the number one thing is providing for my family. And so, you know, kind of said that like retiring my wife, you know, I two young kids and like they deserve a full-time mother, I think. And so was like, all right, I need to buckle up and make that happen for them.

Yeah, yeah, the timing was funny because I quit. so I could ended the school year, year and a half ago and then I didn't go back. I had some other stuff on the side that I was doing too. but like not fully.

funny little things. Yeah, yeah, I did a small number, like, it went well, like, I mean, you've had some guys that have crushed it in Christmas lights on here, and so I was not anywhere in that stratosphere. But it's part time. Sure.

mean, they crushed it after like eight years, but year one is always the smallest, right? So you don't need to compare them.

Hmm.

physical manual labor. Yeah.

Those are the hardest houses to get into because they just have like a long list that they blast out and it's a race to the bottom. Like they just go with the cheapest bidder, but then also, so it's the hardest to get into, but then they're also the lowest margin.


by far. And so, you know, could do one neighborhood of 20 houses would probably do the same profit as just one big custom home. so my whole formula is just, it's pretty straightforward. construction permits have been pulled in your geographic area. downloads of the permits and you can filter by single family homes or basements, whatever. So, you know, I just do single family home.

so you can see, okay, these people have pulled a permit. Let me go see where they are in the process. And it could be, it's not just a permit to, like there's no permit to just frame and drywall. It's probably a permit to what, like expand or redo the kitchen or.

No.

There's not that many custom homes. there's all the every like.

Hmm

the production homes, every one of those houses is a different permit. And if they don't have drywall already, then I just call them, so I will have the builder name and number. Most of the time it will have the builder name and number. Not every city reports it the same way, but most cities will, and Utah at least, will have the builder name and number. So I just cold call them.


They're like, I was in the area, I saw you building the house at 123 Maple Street. Do you have drywall line up on it already? If not, can I give you a bid? And inevitably, they always ask the same exact question. Well, they'll say one of two things. If they answer the phone, they'll say one of two things. They'll say, you know what, thanks, I already have a guy that I'm loyal to, but good luck, whatever. And if that's the case, I just say, well, you know, I totally get that. Can I just give you my name and contact in case anything changes,


So that's one of two things they'll say. The second thing they'll say, if that's not the case, they'll say, oh, well, I mean, I don't know, who else do you work with? What other builders do you work with? And in construction, it's all just about, like, show me, don't tell me. And the best way to do that is to say, like, we built for these guys. And so, you know, lucky enough for me, the drywall company I'm selling for has done work for some of the best custom home builders here in the area.


And so I can just, even when I was first starting out, even though I hadn't done any of my own houses, it's the same crew. So I can just say, no, we built for X, Y, and Z builders.
